data.title: Usability: NVDA is not reciting the "Name" and "shortcut key" for  the menu options present  in the visual studio code appropriately.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VS Code Version: 1.6.1
OS Version:1607
**Steps to Reproduce:**
Prerequisite: NVDA screen reader   need to open.
1.Open visual studio code.
2.Using "Alt + F", key navigate to the "File" menu option.

**Expected Result:**
NVDA should announce the "Name" and the "Shortcut key" for the menu options in the visual studio code.
Ex: NVDA should announce File Menu option Alt+F

**Actual Result:**
NVDA is not announcing the menu options appropriately.
NVDA is announcing "menu sub menu"
Note: Same issue is observed for other menu options(Edit, View, Go, Help)

**User Impact:**
Screen Reader user doesn't get to know that the options corresponds to which Menu bar.

![inspectinformation_visualstudiocodeeditor_filemenuoption](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22956130/21212258/f9990f3e-c2b0-11e6-9d39-67f13f1e0f27.jpg)
![nvda_speechviewerinformation_vscodeeditor_filemenuoption](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22956130/21212263/0175f316-c2b1-11e6-849b-2830ac2cd1b5.jpg)

data.title: Sorting selections

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Feature Request

When a user has multiple selections selected the command would sort the selections and swap them around between the selections. This is in contrast with sort lines which only swaps the lines.

## Scenario 1
Original: 
![1 - original](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211506/6d6cf5a4-c2c7-11e6-96ef-edbc5e8c3543.png)

User selects the lines that she wants sorted:
![2 - sort select](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211513/8c8cb91a-c2c7-11e6-8f5d-2a355f84531f.png)

Uses the command "Sort Lines Ascending" and results in this error:
![3 - error sort](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211528/add2e2b6-c2c7-11e6-9295-123272fd9d9b.png)

## Solution to scenario 1

User performs a multi-selection either using the `alt` key or using the find command:
![4 - sort multiselect](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211557/031169be-c2c8-11e6-8243-0782dbcd4a52.png)

Execute "Sort Selections Ascending" which results in a correct output:
![5 - sort correct](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211566/13c56aa8-c2c8-11e6-98ab-1d7206c1e974.png)

## Scenario 2

This would also work for selection that span multiple lines as seen in the following example: 
![6 - all selection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211612/6e98f8f0-c2c8-11e6-9878-dcf717692052.png)

Which would result in the following erroneous output:
![7 - all sort selection wrong](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211624/7e55223c-c2c8-11e6-9465-8c188ebc04b1.png)

## Solution to scenario 2

![8 - all sort multiselection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211635/90ffcc0c-c2c8-11e6-81be-4edefff5a1dd.png)

![9 - all sort correct](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1409734/21211637/93fde33a-c2c8-11e6-85a9-7bbb8c930a1b.png)

The command should also work with selections that are not adjacent which simplifies sorting functions.

I could probably implement this myself but I want to hear if this is something that should be part of the core product or an extension.

data.title: Allow to set a background image
data.body:
There has been a plugin for it, but I think it has encountered various problems since VS Code 1.6. Furthermore, I think its method (modifying the CSS file it seems) is too hacky anyway. Is it possible to provide this functionality officially? Or maybe provide a better way for plugin authors, so we can get more stable background image plugins?

Thank you very much!

data.title: How to hide explorer without activity bar?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. View -> Hide Activity Bar
2. Ctrl+Shift+E to show the explorer
3. Ctrl+Shift+E again does not hide the explorer
4. Apparently I have to go to View -> Show Activity Bar and use that to hide it.

It would make sense if the command for showing the explorer also hid it. Just like the command for hiding the activity bar also shows it again.

data.title: Proposal: use ACME chords for VSCode terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open terminal
2. Make sure a compile produces an output similar to:
```
go build -i -v
github.com/iron-io/functions
# github.com/iron-io/functions
./main.go:63: expression in go/defer must be function call
```

In this case, instead of relying on linkify, we could use acme's mousechords (http://acme.cat-v.org/mouse)

In this case, highlight while holding right button - or some other acceptable combination - it takes the selected text and take an action, that can be, among possibilities, open the file in the goto address. Thus for the example above, it would open `./main.go:63` in `$PWD`.

data.title: registerCompletionItemProvider problem
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Linux, Solus os

I've created a extension using registerCompletionItemProvider. Before explain everything, this is my code:
```javascript
const selectors = ['html', 'php', 'twig', 'jsp', 'htm'];

const completionItem = {
   provideCompletionItems: () => resolve, // This  is because I'm using a promise function
   resolveCompletionItem: (item, token) => item
}

let action = vscode.languages.registerCompletionItemProvider(selectors, completionItem, '&')
context.subscriptions.push(action);
```
Ok. The code above works fine. When I typing **&**, I get the whole list of items. Obviously, this works in the files extensions that I've predefined. But, the thing is that when I typing something that is insde the list whitout using **&**, I've got the name of the item. Eg.

```
[what I typing] 
cel ------------------> cels;(This is a item insie the whole list) // This should not happend

[when I typing "&"]
& --------------------> a list of all the itmes. // This behavior is right.
```

data.title: Zen Mode could have an option to show only the current tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8
- OS Version: macOS and Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Zen Mode

I love Zen Mode. Thank you. The line of tabs on the top of the app can be just a tad bit distracting, though. It would be great to switch to only a single window at a time; if you move your mouse to the top of the window then the line of tabs should drop down, just as the dropdown menu does when you're in full-screen mode. I imagine that it would be most accommodating to all users to enable hiding of the line of tabs as an option, as opposed to the default.

data.title: Variable name maybe shouldn't be mandatory for OutputEvent
data.body:
If I return multiple objects for an OutputEvent, then only the first is shown, because of this check in debugModel.ts -

`distinct(response.body.variables.filter(v => !!v), v => v.name)`

If I add some unique name, then they are all shown. @isidorn maybe since the name isn't visible, it shouldn't be checked in this case. On the other hand, it's still required on 'Variable' in the protocol, so it could be considered sort of an id. It's easy enough to give them names.

data.title: Zen mode code centre
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.8 - OS Version: OS X 10.12.1 Zen mode is in! I love you guys, thanks for that, been looking forward to it! However, everything tends to hang to the left super heavily, which is not so fun in large monitors. Although I bet it works great on a vertical setup: ![VS Code Zen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3832380/21203753/9c834220-c219-11e6-892a-a3c193df2538.png) I would love it if there were a way to add some left padding of sorts. For now I just turned off the Fullscreen option, changed the background color of my Desktop to match VS Code, and that works to some degree: How other people are doing it: Distraction free mode in IntelliJ tries to centre the code a bit: ![IntelliJ family distraction free mode](https://stanfy.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Distraction-Free-Mode-Android-Studio.png) The Atom Zen mode plugin does something similar: ![Atom Zen](https://i.github-camo.com/6dbae0fe77e4492d6aa9a2c93f39ca4db79c6271/68747470733a2f2f662e636c6f75642e6769746875622e636f6d2f6173736574732f322f323239303435352f63653939653937652d613031642d313165332d383830382d6562656334306539353962342e706e67) If there is a way to do this already and my google-fu failed me I do apologize for that.

data.title: Allow to open a file and goto line without -g option (/path/to/file.ex:123)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.2.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set VSCode to be the default editor for a file type. (for example .ex)
2. Go to the terminal.
3. Command-Click on a URI like /path/to/file.ex:123

It should open to line 123. But it doesn't.

data.title: Support native tabs on macOS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Maximize the current VSCode window (fullscreen)
2. Press Cmd+Shift+N

1.7's behaviour is to spawn the window in a new "application tab" (aka as described in Apple's "merge windows" feature [here](https://support.apple.com/kb/PH25079?locale=en_US&viewlocale=en_US))

New behaviour: It just spawns a totally separate window, on another desktop.

The old behaviour was really useful in being able to juggle a lot of projects at once. It would be really awesome if it went back to that! I tried reverting `window.titleBarStyle` to `native` and then restarting, but no dice.

data.title: eslint not following plugin rule changes that override extend
1.8 update reduces tab bar element visibility in light theme

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.0 (38746938a4ab94f2f57d9e1309c51fd6fb37553d, 2016-12-13T17:38:28.425Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

See screenshot and the notes that follow.  Using the light+ theme (the default light theme), there is a lot more eye strain compared to the previous version.

![screen shot 2016-12-14 at 4 30 35 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20231989/21201993/0111727e-c21b-11e6-8856-5fc8002a4365.png)

The updated rendering has two (possibly three) differences that negatively affect visibility:
(1) Previously there were dark, single pixel lines dividing each tab.  Now there are light, single pixel lines dividing each tab.  I can only see them with strain.
(2) There used to be a dark, single pixel line at the bottom of the tab bar dividing it from the editor, in addition to a subtle drop shadow.  Now the drop shadow is the only visible division.  The shadow-only division makes the line between the non-active (gray) tabs and the editor contents just look like a blur.  I find my eyes straining significantly.
(3) I'm not sure, but it feels like the rendering of the text in the tab bar might be a little blurrier; however this likely not the case--it might just be the eye strain/blur from (1), (2) that gives this impression.

By my eye, it seems that the dark themes might have improved (not sure; don't use them typically).  Nonetheless, the light theme seems to have regressed enough to steer me (reluctantly) towards the dark themes.

If anyone has a 1.7 light+ screenshot handy, please post for comparison.

data.title: Keypair settings misaligned with dictionary settings when using Copy to Settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Win10 64-bit Bld. 1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open settings.json in default Settings window
2. Click the pencil icon next to a dictionary-style setting (e.g. 'files.associations') and click "Copy to Settings"
3. Click the pencil icon next to a keypair-style setting (e.g. `editor.lineHeight`) and click "Copy to Settings"

Result: 

Observe dictionary-style setting is aligned correctly (1 indentation), but has a newline, a comma, and another newline after it which forces the keypair-style setting down. See attached for a screenshot.

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6774110/21201693/f4edcb7e-c219-11e6-958e-545645881ded.PNG)
